solution:
\begin{soln}
  By using continuity of $f$ at $x=1$, we get that
  $\forall\,\eps > 0$ $\exists \, \delta > 0$ such that
  for all $x\in [0,1]$,
  \[
    |x-1| < \delta \implies |f(x)-f(1)| < \eps
  \]
  that is
  \[
    f(1)-\eps\le f(x)\le f(1)+\eps\quad
    \forall\, x \in (1-\delta, 1+\delta)
  .\]
  
  Let $M = \max_{t\in [0,1]}f(t)$, which exists as $f$ is
  continuous. Then we have
  \begin{align*}
    \int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    &= \int_{0}^{1-\delta} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    + \int_{1-\delta}^{1} f(x)x^n \mathrm{d}x \\
    &\le \int_{0}^{1-\delta} Mx^n \mathrm{d}x
    + \int_{1-\delta}^{1} (f(1)+\eps)x^n \mathrm{d}x \\
    &= \frac{M(1-\delta)^{n+1}}{n+1}+\frac{(f(1)+\eps)
    (1-(1-\delta)^{n+1})}{n+1}
  \end{align*}
  which implies
  \[
    n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^n \mathrm{d}x
    \le \frac{n}{n+1}\cdot M(1-\delta)^{n+1}
    +\frac{n}{n+1}(f(1)+\eps)
    (1-(1-\delta)^{n+1})
  .\]
  Similarly, we also get
  \begin{align*}
    \int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    &= \int_{0}^{1-\delta} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    + \int_{1-\delta}^{1} f(x)x^n \mathrm{d}x \\
    &> \int_{1-\delta}^{1} f(x)x^n \mathrm{d}x \\
    &\ge \int_{1-\delta}^{1} (f(1)-\eps)x^n \mathrm{d}x \\
    &= \frac{(f(1)-\eps)(1-(1-\delta)^{n+1})}{n+1}
  \end{align*}
  which implies
  \[
    n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    > \frac{n}{n+1}(f(1)-\eps)(1-(1-\delta)^{n+1})
  .\]
  Let
  \[
    a_{n}=\frac{n}{n+1}(f(1)-\eps)
    (1-(1-\delta)^{n+1})
  \]
  and
  \[
    b_{n}=\frac{n}{n+1}\cdot M(1-\delta)^{n+1}
    +\frac{n}{n+1}(f(1)+\eps)
    (1-(1-\delta)^{n+1})
  .\]
  Therefore, we now have
  \[
    a_{n}
    \le n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x \le
    b_{n}
  .\]
  
  Note that $\lim_{n \to \oo} a_{n} = f(1)-\eps$ and
  $\lim_{n \to \oo} b_{n}=f(1)+\eps$. This suggests that
  the sequences $\left\{ a_{n} \right\}_{n \ge 1}$ and
  $\left\{ b_{n} \right\}_{n \ge 1}$ are bounded.
  Therefore, $n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x$
  is also bounded and hence
  $\liminf_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x$
  and $\limsup_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x$
  exist.

  Using the following limits in our preceding inequality,
  we get
  \[
    f(1)-\eps\le
    \liminf_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    \le f(1)+\eps
  \]
  and
  \[
    f(1)-\eps\le
    \limsup_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    \le f(1)+\eps
  \]
  for any arbitrary $\eps>0$. Considering small enough
  $\eps$, we get that
  \[
    \liminf_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    =\limsup_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x
    =f(1)
  \]
  which implies
  $\lim_{n \to \oo} n\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^{n}\mathrm{d}x$
  exists and is equal to $f(1)$.
\end{soln}
